author: @vladimirtchuiev2218
text: It's easier to build a decent bot if you have some domain knowledge. For example, voidrays in general are bad vs Terran because of marines, vikings, and ravens. Colossi are more of a safe bet. 22 workers per mining base is optimal, whether to go to 66 or 88 depends on your play style preference I guess. But an interesting series nonetheless, I'm more interested in the deep learning side of things, for example a network that can handle building placement or general army movements and high level decisions. Building an end to end reinforcement learning algorithm for SC2 that works is borderline impossible without google-grade hardware.

author: @fourZerglings
text: This is incorrect, iteration is not reliable time measure. Use state.game_loop instead, which is exact game time. 16 game_loop equals 1 in-game second. 22.4 game_loop equals 1 real time second (due to game playing on Faster: 16 * 1.4 = 22.4)

author: @Dpaq13
text: 22 workers per base. 16 in minerals + 2*(3 in gas).  With three expansions you want 66 for peak efficiency.  Any more than that will give you diminishing returns.

author: @marcuslanvers5138
text: the best amount of workers for your 3 base build should probbly be 66, you want 16 workers at your mineralline (8 patches and optimal 2 per patch) + 6 in gas per base. That makes 16*3 + 6*3 = 66. Thats what i was going for as terran all the time, maybe you can go a littel bit higher but any lower will hurt your economy. So you are actually pretty optimal :D

author: @manuelk.8273
text: You can use state.game_loop to approximate the current game time. According to the documentation there are 22.4 ticks ("gameloops") per seconds (or 1344ticks per minute) in the fast mode. Source: https://github.com/Blizzard/s2client-proto/blob/master/docs/protocol.md#game-speed

author: @omiyodranawa9430
text: If you don't like suggestions skip this comment.  TL:DR Check out lua programming language. Long version : Hey! Unrelated comment. I wanted to suggest you look at a very light-weight high level programming language called lua. It's miles faster than python, can work with libraries/modules, super easy to learn, is supported by a tensor processing library ( for machine learning ofc) called called Torch ( see torch.ch ), has a very popular JIT compiler that makes it even faster called LuaJIT, and can even probably include some C libraries and dlls if I'm not wrong (with luajit at least anyway). Torch is not a static-graph ML tool though, it's dynamic. Maybe you find that bad but perhaps you can learn a new ML way of thinking by trying it. Yes there is PyTorch but I'm mainly interested in Lua.If you want IDE that has demos on it and downloads the binaries of lua for you, I suggest using ZeroBraneStudio.  Ahoy!~

author: @benjaminjaton3597
text: Curious to see how far you're going to go with this. Right now your approach is to write a strategy (~stalker/voidray) and then to use deep learning to optimize it as much as possible. Usually a player does a round of "scouting" around minute 1/2 with a probe to get info on the opponent's position+strategy, and decide on what to build accordingly. So the opponent's existing/pending buildings and units could be part of the features for the learning. As a protoss you can also build "observers" which are "invisible" units that can spy on the enemy base, getting you better intel so that you make better strategic choices, like start mass producing a certain kind of unit or anticipating where the opponent will attack. The number of possible inputs AND outputs is just insane. But so fun, best of luck!

text: 50 or so workers are fine for protoss. Zerg need much more (~80). Also, only Terran can lift up their buildings and move protoss and zerg cannot. Also, sc2ai allows Python-sc2 bots http://wiki.sc2ai.net/Main_Page . And please tell if there is a way to do testing without rendering the matches. for one or two matches its fine but if I want to test 1000 matches(deep learning will need that) it will be a lot faster without rendering

author: @RuskiRozpierdalacz
text: Awesome series. I may advice using fixed amount of stargates and gateways per each mining nexus. (not depleted ones) I would try 2-2,5 gateways per nexus plus about 0,75-1 stargates per nexus, rounded down, plus add code to place extra ones in case of oversupply (more than 700-800 minerals) Also I would order placing new nexuses based on supply, so in case of early fight you would have less supply, and bot wouldn't expand too fast.  Also consider using upgrades in forge and cybernetics core in later stages of game (over 120 supply)
